## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-09-29T12:26:35Z
## Message ID: 20230929-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-09-29T12:05Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-09-27T12:00Z (see notifications 20230927-AL-001, 20230927-AL-002) are caused by CME with ID 2023-09-22T02:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001) and CME with ID 2023-09-22T07:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230922-AL-001, 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-09-27T12:00:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 20, 2023 - September 26, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-09-27T21:46:08Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-09-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-09-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20230927-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 9 M-class flares, 3 O-type CMEs, and 7 C-type CMEs (see details below). 

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact Missions near Earth:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impact (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-09-20T15:05Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-09-23T20:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 3-4 (below minor)
                                       See notifications 20230921-AL-001, 20230921-AL-002
                                       The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.
2023-09-22T02:24Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-09-24T08:42Z, Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor)
                                       See notifications 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001
                                       Ensemble results: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-22_ncmes2_sims24_LAHAINA047/Detailed_results_20230922_060600_ncmes2_sims24_LAHAINA047.txt
                                       The arrival of this CME was detected at L1 around 2023-09-24T19:52Z.
2023-09-22T07:36Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-09-24T08:42Z, Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor)
                                       See notifications 20230922-AL-001, 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001
                                       Ensemble results: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-22_ncmes2_sims24_LAHAINA047/Detailed_results_20230922_060600_ncmes2_sims24_LAHAINA047.txt
                                       The arrival of this CME was detected at L1 around 2023-09-24T19:52Z.
2023-09-22T22:24Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-09-25T22:48Z, Kp index 2-4 (below minor)
                                       See notification 20230923-AL-003
                                       The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.


It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-09-20T15:05Z    STEREO A at 2023-09-23T17:00Z (glancing blow) (see notifications 20230921-AL-001, 20230921-AL-002).
2023-09-22T02:24Z    STEREO A at 2023-09-24T05:44Z (see notifications 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001).
2023-09-22T07:36Z    STEREO A at 2023-09-24T05:44Z (see notifications 20230922-AL-001, 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001).
2023-09-22T22:24Z    STEREO A at 2023-09-25T18:29Z (see notification 20230923-AL-003).
2023-09-24T10:00Z    Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-25T04:34Z (see notification 20230924-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5.67 for the reporting period (see notifications 20230924-AL-003, 20230924-AL-004, 20230925-AL-001). The highest value of Kp = 5.67 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2023-09-24T18:00Z to 2023-09-25T00:00Z. This enhanced geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-09-24T19:52Z (see notification 20230924-AL-002) which was associated with a combined arrival of the O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2023-09-22T02:24Z (see notifications 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001) and the O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2023-09-22T07:36Z (see notifications 20230922-AL-001, 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001). Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-09-24T22:30Z (see notifications 20230924-AL-005 and 20230924-AL-006). The arrival of these CMEs were also detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2023-09-24T18:49Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt remained elevated above the threshold of 1000 pfu through most of the reporting period following a threshold crossing observed during the previous reporting period at 2023-09-19T14:55Z (see notifications 20230919-AL-004, 20230919-AL-005. 20230921-AL-005, and 20230923-AL-002). These elevated energetic electron flux levels were likely associated with a possible combination arrival of an S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-09-14T23:12Z (see notification 20230915-AL-001), and/or the arrival of a C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-09-16T09:12Z (see notifications 20230916-AL-001, 20230916-AL-002, and 20230917-AL-001), and the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream. Towards the end of the reporting period on 2023-09-24, the energetic electron flux levels dropped below the 1000 pfu threshold and remained below the threshold for the remainder of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A remained below threshold and at near-background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-09-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-10-03T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor to moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently eight Active Regions across the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13435 (N09W61) produced five M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to produce notable flaring activity before it is expected to rotate off the Earth-facing disk towards the end of the outlook period. Active Region 13450 (S20E80) was recently numbered and may exhibit increased flaring activity during the outlook period.  

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole currently centered around N36E09 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2023-10-01. An additional coronal hole currently centered around N05E40 could also become geoeffective towards the end of the reporting period on or around 2023-10-03. The >2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in EarthÂ’s outer radiation belt recently crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu starting at 2023-09-27T12:00Z (see notifications  20230927-AL-001 and 20230927-AL-002). This ongoing radiation belt enhancement is associated with the combined arrival of the O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2023-09-22T02:24Z (see notifications 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001) and the O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2023-09-22T07:36Z (see notifications 20230922-AL-001, 20230922-AL-002, 20230923-AL-001) which is likely to persist through the beginning of the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2023-09-27T12:00Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels may be caused by the arrival of CME with ID 2023-09-22T02:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230922-AL-002 and 20230923-AL-001) and  CME with ID 2023-09-22T07:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230922-AL-001, 20230922-AL-002, and 20230923-AL-001). The arrival of these CMEs were detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-09-24T19:52Z (see notification 20230924-AL-002).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-09-27T12:00:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

This event is associated with Magnetopause Crossing with ID 2023-09-24T22:30:00-MPC-001 (see notifications 20230924-AL-005 and 20230924-AL-006) and Geomagnetic Storm with ID 2023-09-24T18:00:00-GST-001 (see notifications 20230924-AL-003, 20230924-AL-004, and 20230925-AL-001).

## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-09-24T22:30Z.

The activity is associated with Geomagnetic Storm with ID 2023-09-24T18:00:00-GST-001 (see notifications 20230924-AL-003 and 20230924-AL-004) and Interplanetary Shock with ID 2023-09-24T19:52:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20230924-AL-002). The Interplanetary Shock may be associated with the arrival of CME with ID with 2023-09-22T02:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230922-AL-002 and 20230923-AL-001) and/or CME with ID 2023-09-22T07:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230922-AL-001, 20230922-AL-002, and 20230923-AL-001). The arrival signature is still developing and analysis is ongoing.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2023-09-24T22:30:00-MPC-001.

## Summary:

O-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-09-24T10:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~1099 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 33 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 155/13 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-09-24T10:00:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Solar Orbiter.  The leading edge of the CME may reach Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-25T04:34Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-09-22T22:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~786 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 19 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 2/-12 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-09-22T22:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A. The leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2023-09-25T18:29Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-09-25T22:48Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor).

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-09-21T14:55Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-09-19T14:55Z (see notifications 20230919-AL-004 and 20230919-AL-005) may be caused by the arrival of CME with ID 2023-09-14T23:12:00-CME-001 (see notification 20230915-AL-001) and/or CME with ID 2023-09-16T09:12:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230916-AL-001, 20230916-AL-002, and 20230917-AL-001), as well as a possible coronal hole high speed stream. The arrival of these CMEs may have been detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE around 2023-09-18T12:58Z (see notification 20230918-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-09-19T14:55:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact Missions near Earth:

                                       Ensemble results: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-14_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA044/Detailed_results_20230914_072400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA044.txt
                                       The arrival of this CME was detected at L1 around 2023-09-17T01:53Z.

                                       See notification 20230915-AL-001
                                       The arrival of this CME was possibly detected at L1 around 2023-09-18T12:58Z.
2023-09-16T09:12Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-09-19T18:55Z, Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor)
                                       See notifications 20230916-AL-001, 20230916-AL-002, and 20230917-AL-001
                                       Ensemble results: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA045/Detailed_results_20230916_150400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA045.txt
                                       The arrival of this CME was possibly detected at L1 around 2023-09-18T12:58Z.


It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-09-14T07:24Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-15T09:03Z, STEREO A at 2023-09-16T19:22Z, OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-16T22:00Z (glancing blow), and Juno at 2023-09-28T02:00Z (minor impact) (see notifications 20230914-AL-001, 20230915-AL-002).
2023-09-14T23:12Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-16T08:42Z and STEREO A at 2023-09-18T06:20Z (see notification 20230915-AL-001).
2023-09-16T07:09Z    Mars at 2023-09-21T22:00Z (minor impact) and Lucy at 2023-09-25T00:00Z (minor impact).
2023-09-16T09:12Z    STEREO A at 2023-09-19T14:31Z and Juno at 2023-10-02T00:00Z (minor impact) (see notifications 20230916-AL-001, 20230916-AL-002, and 20230917-AL-001).


Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6.67 for the reporting period (see notifications 20230919-AL-001, 20230919-AL-002, and 20230919-AL-003). The highest value of Kp=6.67 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-09-19T03:00Z-06:00Z. This enhanced geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-09-18T12:58Z (see notification 20230918-AL-001) which may have possibly been associated with a combination arrival of an S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-09-14T23:12Z (see notification 20230915-AL-001), and/or the arrival of a C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-09-16T09:12Z (see notifications 20230916-AL-001, 20230916-AL-002, and 20230917-AL-001), and the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream. Analysis of this arrival signature is ongoing. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-09-18T17:54Z (see notifications 20230918-AL-002 and 20230918-AL-003). This interplanetary shock was also detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2023-09-18T09:04Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu starting at 2023-09-19T14:55Z and remained elevated through the end of the reporting period (see notifications 20230919-AL-004 and 0230919-AL-005). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely associated with the possible arrival of the S-type and C-type CMEs described above and/or the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A remained below threshold and at near-background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-09-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-09-26T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently ten numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13435 (N09E30) produced four M-class flares during the reporting period and is likely to exhibit additional flaring activity during the outlook period. Additionally, Active Region 13429 (N12W79) produced five M-class flares during the reporting period and could produce additional flaring activity as it rotates off the Earth-facing disk during the beginning of the outlook period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Coronal hole structures currently centered around N00W20 and N40W00 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO) may become geoeffective on or around 2023-09-22 and 2023-09-23 respectively. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation is anticipated to remain elevated during the outlook period, having most recently crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-09-20T13:35Z (see notifications 20230919-AL-004 and 20230919-AL-005).

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2023-09-19T14:55Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels may be caused by the arrival of the CME with ID 2023-09-14T23:12:00-CME-001 (see notification 20230915-AL-001) and possible coronal hole high speed stream reaching a maximum speed of approximately 680 km/s. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 560 km/s. Analysis is ongoing.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-09-19T14:55:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

This event is associated with Interplanetary Shock with ID 2023-09-18T12:58:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20230918-AL-001), Magnetopause Crossing with ID 2023-09-18T17:54:00-MPC-001 (see notifications 20230918-AL-002, 20230918-AL-003) and Geomagnetic Storm with ID 2023-09-19T00:00:00-GST-001 (see notifications 20230919-AL-001, 20230919-AL-002, 20230919-AL-003).

## Summary:

A space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere was observed. Geomagnetic Kp index reached a maximum level of 6.67 (strong) during the synoptic period 2023-09-19T03:00Z to 2023-09-19T06:00Z. Geomagnetic activity during the most recent synoptic periods between 2023-09-19T06:00Z to 2023-09-19T12:00Z has since subsided with observed Kp levels of 4.33 (below minor).

The storm was likely caused by the combined arrival of the CME with ID 2023-09-14T23:12:00-CME-001 (see notification 20230915-AL-001) and possible coronal hole high speed stream. Analysis of this arrival signature is ongoing.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions may have been impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-09-19T00:00:00-GST-001.

## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-09-18T17:54Z.

This modeled magnetopause crossing is associated with the Interplanetary Shock with ID 2023-09-18T12:58:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20230918-AL-001) which may be associated with combined arrival of CME with ID 2023-09-14T23:12:00-CME-001 (see notification 20230915-AL-001) and possibly a coronal hole high speed stream. The arrival signature is still developing and is under analysis.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2023-09-18T17:54:00-MPC-001.

## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-09-16T09:12:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20230916-AL-002). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2023-09-19T03:46Z and 2023-09-19T18:56Z (average arrival 2023-09-19T11:18Z) for 100% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-09-19T07:38Z and 2023-09-19T23:00Z (average arrival 2023-09-19T15:15Z) for 95% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 79% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA045/20230916_150400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA045_anim_tim-den.gif

https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA045/20230916_150400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA045_arrival_STA.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA045/Detailed_results_20230916_150400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA045.txt

The leading edge of the CME will reach Juno at 2023-09-28T02:00Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-15T09:03Z, STEREO A at 2023-09-16T19:22Z, and the flank of the CME will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-16T22:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-09-16T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor).

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor levels during this reporting period with 7 M-class flares, 11 C-type CMEs, and 2 O-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-09-07T19:24Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-09-10T23:30Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-4 (below minor) (see notification 20230908-AL-003). The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.

Additionally, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-09-11T01:48Z may impact give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-09-14T01:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-4 (below minor) (see notification 20230911-AL-002).

It was estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-09-07T19:24Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-09T09:00Z, STEREO A at 2023-09-10T21:00Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-11T04:00Z (glancing blows) (See notification 20230908-AL-003)
2023-09-08T11:48Z    Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-09T08:30Z, Lucy at 2023-09-14T12:00Z (minor impact) and Mars at 2023-09-14T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notifications 20230908-AL-001 and 20230908-AL-002)
2023-09-10T17:24Z    Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-12T08:29Z (see notification 20230911-AL-001)
2023-09-11T01:48Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-12T15:30Z and STEREO A at 2023-09-13T21:30Z (glancing blows) (see notification 20230911-AL-002)
2023-09-11T11:00Z    Mars at 2023-09-16T20:28Z, Lucy at 2023-09-19T08:03Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-13T04:00Z (glancing blow)
2023-09-11T23:12Z    Lucy at 2023-09-16T16:44Z, Mars at 2023-09-14T23:13Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-12T22:33Z (see notifications 20230912-AL-004 and 20230912-AL-007)

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5.67 for the reporting period (see notifications 20230912-AL-005 and 20230912-AL-006). The highest value of Kp=5.67 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-09-12T15:00Z-18:00Z. This was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-09-12T10:18Z which may have been associated with the arrival of a CME not detected in available coronagraph imagery (see notification 20230912-AL-002). This arrival also caused a magnetospheric compression with simulations indicating that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-09-12T13:46Z (see notifications 20230912-AL-001 and 20230912-AL-003).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were at near background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to minor this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-09-13T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-09-19T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor to moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the solar disk. Active Region 13425 (N25W25) produced three M-class flares and Active Region 13423 (N16W50) produced one M-class flare during the reporting period. Both Active Regions may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity during the outlook period. Additionally, an unnumbered Active Region beyond the eastern limb might have produced notable far-sided CME activity during the reporting period and it is possible this active region could rotate onto the Earth-facing disk during the latter part of the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Observed coronal hole structures centered around S25W50 and N05W25 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective starting on or around 2023-09-14 and 2023-09-16, respectively.

The cause of this storm is still under analysis.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-09-12T15:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 

This event is associated with Interplanetary Shock with ID 2023-09-12T10:18:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20230912-AL-002) and Magnetopause Crossing with ID 2023-09-12T13:46:00-MPC-001 (see notifications 20230912-AL-001 and 20230912-AL-003). The Interplanetary Shock is likely caused by a CME that was was undetectable in coronagraph imagery, possibly associated with eruptions visible on the Earth-facing disk around September 8-10. Analysis is ongoing.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 30, 2023 - September 05, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-09-06T20:31:43Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-08-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-09-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20230906-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 7 M-class flares, 4 O-type CMEs, and 14 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-08-30T22:12Z may impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-09-02T13:09Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 5-7 (minor to strong) (see notification 20230831-AL-001). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 24 members which estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-09-02T05:40Z and 2023-09-02T23:22Z (average arrival 2023-09-02T13:36Z) for 100% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicated that there was a 60% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate). Full details of the modeled event are available here: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-01_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA041/Detailed_results_20230830_221205_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA041.txt (see notification 20230901-AL-009). The arrival of this CME may have been detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 late on 2023-09-02. The arrival signature is still under analysis. 

Additionally, it was estimated that the O-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-09-01T03:24Z may reach NASA missions near Earth at 2023-09-03T15:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-4 (below minor) (see notifications 20230901-AL-005, 20230901-AL-007, 20230901-AL-008, and 20230902-AL-001). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 24 members which estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between 2023-09-02T18:53Z and 2023-09-03T09:06Z (average arrival 2023-09-03T02:47Z) for 91% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there was a 73% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor). Full details of the modeled event are available here: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-01_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042/Detailed_results_20230901_032400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042.txt (see notification 20230902-AL-001). The arrival of this CME has not been detected at L1. 

Furthermore, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-09-01T23:12Z may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at 2023-09-05T12:30Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-3 (below minor) (see notification 20230902-AL-002). The arrival of this CME may have been detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2023-09-05T14:38Z (see notification 20230905-AL-003) and at STEREO A around 2023-09-05T10:50Z. 

It was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact other locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-08-30T22:12Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-02T18:12Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-01T12:41Z, and STEREO A at 2023-09-02T09:34Z (see notification 20230831-AL-001)
2023-09-01T03:24Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-03T22:00Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2023-09-03T14:15Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-02T16:50Z, and Juno at 2023-09-13T16:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20230901-AL-008)
2023-09-01T23:12Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-05T18:00Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2023-09-05T08:00Z (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-04T01:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230902-AL-002)
2023-09-03T00:36Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-05T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230903-AL-005)
2023-09-03T05:24Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-05T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230903-AL-005)
2023-09-03T09:12Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-05T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230903-AL-005)
2023-09-05T14:00Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-06T21:56Z (see notification 20230905-AL-004)
2023-09-05T20:36Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-09-07T01:00Z (see notification 20230906-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5.67 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-09-03T00:00Z-03:00Z. This enhancement of geomagnetic activity was likely caused by the combined arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2023-09-01 with possibly the CME first visible in coronagraph imagery at 2023-08-30T22:12Z and/or 2023-09-01T03:24Z (see notifications 20230903-AL-001 and 20230903-AL-002). 

The >2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt initially crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-09-05T15:25Z and has remained elevated throughout the reporting period (see notifications 20230905-AL-001 and 20230905-AL-002). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by the coronal hole high speed stream and/or CMEs arrivals mentioned above (see notifications 20230831-AL-001 and 20230901-AL-009).

Additionally, there was a solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A. At GOES, the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2023-09-01T04:30Z (see notifications 20230901-AL-002 and 20230901-AL-003). At STEREO A, the flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-09-01T04:34Z (see notification 20230901-AL-004). Finally, at SOHO, the flux of the 15.8-39.8 MeV protons channel and the flux of the 28.2-50.1 MeV protons channel exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-09-01T05:05Z (see notification 20230901-AL-006). This solar energetic particle event was associated with a long-duration M1.2-class flare which peaked at 2023-09-01T03:52Z from Active Region 13413 and subsequent O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph imagery at 2023-09-01T03:24Z (see notifications 20230901-AL-005, 20230901-AL-007, 20230901-AL-008, 20230902-AL-001). The particle environment is currently near-background levels at all locations. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been high this week due to the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A, and the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-09-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date: 2023-09-12T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate to high levels during the outlook period. There are currently eight numbered active regions on the solar disk. Active Region 13421 (N14W23) produced three M-class flares and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity as it traverses the Earth-facing disk. Additionally, an unnumbered Active Region around latitude N25 will be rotating soon onto the east limb as seen in SDO and STEREO A EUV imagery.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at minor to moderate levels during the outlook period due to increases in geomagnetic activity associated with minor coronal hole structures centered around S01E05, N32W05, and a more prominent coronal hole centered around S32E40. The first two coronal holes should cross the central meridian on 2023-09-07 and may become geoeffective starting around 2023-09-10. The more prominent coronal hole should cross the central meridian on 2023-09-09 and may become geoeffective starting around 2023-09-12.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2023-09-05T15:25Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by a coronal hole high speed stream starting on 2023-09-01, reaching a maximum solar wind speed of approximately 570 km/s. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 435 km/s.

Additional influences to the elevated electron flux levels may be caused by one or more CME arrivals, including influence from the CME with ID 2023-08-30T22:12:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230831-AL-001 and 20230901-AL-009) and possibly the CME with ID 2023-09-01T03:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230901-AL-005, 20230901-AL-007, 20230901-AL-008, and 20230902-AL-001). Analysis of the arrival signatures at L1 is ongoing.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-09-05T15:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

This high speed stream arrival and possible CME arrival are associated with a geomagnetic storm with ID 2023-09-03T00:00:00-GST-001 (see notifications 20230903-AL-001 and 20230903-AL-002). Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 5.67 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2023-09-03T00:00Z to 2023-09-03T03:00Z.

## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 5.67 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2023-09-03T00:00Z to 2023-09-03T03:00Z. 

The storm is likely caused by coronal hole high speed stream effects combined with influence from the CME with ID 2023-08-30T22:12:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230831-AL-001 and 20230901-AL-009) and possibly the CME with ID 2023-09-01T03:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230901-AL-005, 20230901-AL-007, 20230901-AL-008, and 20230902-AL-001). The arrival signature is still developing and the cause is still under analysis. 

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-09-03T00:00:00-GST-001.

## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-09-01T03:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20230901-AL-008). 

### Notification information (Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, OSIRIS-REx, Missions Near Earth)

Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2023-09-02T16:20Z and 2023-09-03T12:12Z (average arrival 2023-09-03T00:12Z) for 95% of simulations.

Additionally, the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-09-02T18:53Z and 2023-09-03T09:06Z (average arrival 2023-09-03T02:47Z) for 91% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 73% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-01_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042/20230901_032400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-01_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042/20230901_032400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-01_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042/20230901_032400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-01_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042/20230901_032400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-09-01_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042/20230901_032400_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA042_STA_stack.gif

## Notes: This CME event is also predicted to have impacts at OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-03T22:00Z and Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-02T16:50Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20230901-AL-008).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-08-30T22:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~729 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -7/6 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-08-30T22:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-02T18:12Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-01T12:41Z, and STEREO A at 2023-09-02T09:34Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-09-02T13:09Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 5-7 (minor to strong).
